article.title: Changes in Nuclear Shape and Gene Expression in Response to Simulated Microgravity Are LINC Complex-Dependent
article.abstract: Microgravity is known to affect the organization of the cytoskeleton, cell and nuclear morphology and to elicit differential expression of genes associated with the cytoskeleton, focal adhesions and the extracellular matrix.

sections.introduction: The nucleus is the largest organelle of the cell and homeostatic control of its shape and position are known to be crucial for cellular functions such as cell migration, cell division and the regulation of gene expression.
sections.methods: Human breast epithelial cells (MCF 10A from ATCC), MCF 10A SS-GFP-KDEL and MCF 10A SS-GFP-SUN1L-KDEL cells (created by Dr. Tanmay Lele and Dr. Kyle Roux [21,25]) were a kind gift to us.
sections.results: We first established whether the nuclear shape of MCF 10A cells is responsive to clinostat-induced SMG.
sections.discussion: A highly reproducible suite of effects were observed in cells exposed to altered gravity relating to the reorganization of their cytoskeleton and cell adhesion proteins,

experimental_factors.organism_raw: human breast epithelial cells (MCF 10A from ATCC)

article.insights_summary: The LINC complex plays a critical role in transferring mechanical signals from the ECM and the forces generated within the cytoplasm to the nucleus.
article.acknowledgments: This work was supported by the NASA Postdoctoral Program (NPP) administered by Universities Space Research Association (USRA) and the NASA Space Biology Program.
